verses.text: When the Saviour, Heracleon says, calls him a prophet and Elijah, He is speaking not of John himself, but of his surroundings; but when He calls him greater than the prophets and than those who are born of women, then He is describing the character of John himself.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:15
verses.text: When John, on the other hand, is asked about himself, his answers relate to himself, not to his surroundings.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:16
verses.text: This we have examined as carefully as possible, comparing each of the terms in question with the statements of Heracleon, lest he should not have expressed himself quite accurately.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:17
verses.text: For how it comes that the statements that he is Elijah and that he is a prophet apply to those about him, but the statement that he is the voice of one crying in the wilderness, to himself, no attempt whatever is made to show.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:18
verses.text: Heracleon only gives an illustration, namely, this: His surroundings were, so to speak, his clothes, and other than himself, and when he was asked about his clothes, if he were his clothes, he could not answer "Yes".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:19
verses.text: Now that his being Elijah, who was to come, was his clothes, is scarcely consistent, so far as I can see, with Heracleon's views; it might consist, perhaps, with the exposition we ourselves gave of the words, "In the spirit and power of Elijah;" it might, in a sense, be said that this spirit of Elijah is equivalent to the soul of John.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:20
verses.text: He then goes on to try to determine why those who were sent by the Jews to question John were priests and levites, and he answers by no means badly, that it was incumbent on such persons, being devoted to the service of God, to busy themselves and to make enquiries about such matters.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:21
verses.text: When he goes on, however, to say that it was "because John was of the levitical tribe," this is less well considered.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:22
verses.text: We raised the question ourselves above, and saw that if the Jews who were sent knew John's birth, it was not open to them to ask if he was Elijah.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:23
verses.text: Then, again, in dealing with the question, "Art thou the prophet?" Heracleon does not regard the addition of the article as having any special force, and says, "They asked him if he were a prophet, wishing to know this more general fact".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:24
verses.text: Again, not Heracleon alone, but, so far as I am informed, all those who diverge from our views, as if they had not been able to deal with a trifling ambiguity and to draw the proper distinction, suppose John to be greater than Elijah and than all the prophets.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:25
verses.text: The words are, "Of those born of women there is none greater than John;" but this admits of two meanings, that John is greater than they all, or again, that some of them are equal to him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:26
verses.text: For though many of the prophets were equal to him, still it might be true in respect of the grace bestowed on him, that none of them was greater than he.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:27
verses.text: He regards it as confirming the view that John was greater, that "he is predicted by Isaiah;" for no other of all those who uttered prophecies was held worthy by God of this distinction.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:28
verses.text: This, however, is a venturesome statement and implies some disrespect of what is called the Old Testament, and total disregard of the fact that Elijah himself was the subject of prophecy.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:29
verses.text: For Elijah is prophesied by Malachi, who says, "Behold, I send unto you Elijah, the Tishbite, who shall restore the heart of the father to the son".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:30
verses.text: Josiah, too, as we read in third Kings, was predicted by name by the prophet who came out of Judah; for he said, Jeroboam also being present at the altar, "Thus saith the Lord, Behold a son is born to David, his name is Josiah".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:31
verses.text: There are some also who say that Samson was predicted by Jacob, when he said, "Dan shall judge his own people, he is as one tribe in Israel," for Samson who judged Israel was of the tribe of Dan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 12:32
verses.text: So much by way of evidence of the rashness of the statement that John alone was the subject of prophecy, made by Heracleon in his attempted explanation of the words, "I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:1
verses.text: John I.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:2
Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:3
verses.text: Of the Baptism of John, that of Elijah, and that of Christ.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:4
verses.text: And they that were sent were of the Pharisees.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:5
verses.text: And they asked him, and said unto him, "Why baptizest thou then, if thou art not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet?" Those who sent from Jerusalem the priests and levites who asked John these questions, having learned who John was not, and who he was, preserve a decent silence, as if tacitly assenting and indicating that they accepted what was said, and saw that baptism was suited to a voice crying in the wilderness for the preparing of the way of the Lord.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:6
verses.text: But the Pharisees being, as their name indicates, a divided and seditious set of people, show that they do not agree with the Jews of the metropolis and with the ministers of the service of God, the priests and levites.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:7
verses.text: They send envoys who deal in rebukes, and so far as their power extends debar him from baptizing; their envoys ask, Why baptizest thou, then, if thou art not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet? And if we were to stitch together into one statement what is written in the various Gospels, we should say that at this time they spoke as is here reported, but that at a later time, when they wished to received baptism, they heard the address of John: "Generations of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come? Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:8
verses.text: This is what the Baptist says in Matthew, when he sees many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, without, it is clear, having the fruits of repentance, and pharisaically boasting in themselves that they had Abraham for their father.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:9
verses.text: For this they are rebuked by John, who has the zeal of Elijah according to the communication of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:10
verses.text: For that is a rebuking word, "Think not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham for our father," and that is the word of a teacher, when he speaks of those who for their stony hearts are called unbelieving stones, and says that by the power of God these stones may be changed into children of Abraham; for they were present to the eyes of the prophet and did not shrink from his divine glance.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:11
verses.text: Hence his words: "I say unto you that God is able of these stones to raise up children to Abraham".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:12
verses.text: And since they came to his baptism without having done fruits meet for repentance, he says to them most appropriately, "Already is the axe laid to the root of the tree; every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:13
verses.text: This is as much as to say to them: Since you have come to baptism without having done fruits meet for repentance, you are a tree that does not bring forth good fruit and which has to be cut down by the most sharp and piercing axe of the Word which is living and powerful and sharper than every two-edged sword.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:14
verses.text: The estimation in which the Pharisees held themselves is also set forth by Luke in the passage: "Two men went up to the temple to pray, the one a Pharisee and the other a publican.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:15
verses.text: And the Pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself: God, I thank Thee that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even as this publican".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:16
verses.text: The result of this speech is that the publican goes down to his house justified rather than the Pharisee, and the lesson is drawn, that every one who exalts himself is abased.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:17
verses.text: They came, then, in the character in which the Saviour's reproving words described them, as hypocrites to John's baptism, nor does it escape the Baptist's observation that they have the poison of vipers under their tongue and the poison of asps, for "the poison of asps is under their tongue".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:18
verses.text: The figure of serpents rightly indicates their temper, and it is plainly revealed in their better question: "Why baptizest thou then, if thou art not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet?" To these I would fain reply, if it be the case that the Christ and Elijah and the prophet baptize, but that the voice crying in the wilderness has no authority to do so, "Most harshly, my friends, do you question the messenger sent before the face of Christ to prepare His way before Him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:19
verses.text: The mysteries which belong to this point are all hidden to you; for Jesus being, whether you will or not, the Christ, did not Himself baptize but His disciples, He who was Himself the prophet.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:20
verses.text: And how have you come to believe that Elijah who is to come will baptize?" He did not baptize the logs upon the altar in the times of Ahab, though they needed such a bath to be burned up, what time the Lord appeared in fire.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:21
verses.text: No, he commands the priests to do this for him, and that not only once; for he says, "Do it a second time," upon which they did it a second time, and "Do it a third time," and they did it a third time.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:22
verses.text: If, then, he did not at that time himself baptize but left the work to others, how was he to baptize at the time spoken of by Malachi? Christ, then, does not baptize with water, but His disciples.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:23
verses.text: He reserves for Himself to baptize with the Holy Spirit and with fire.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:24
verses.text: Now Heracleon accepts the speech of the Pharisees as distinctly implying that the office of baptizing belonged to the Christ and Elijah and to every prophet, for he uses these words, "Whose office alone it is to baptize".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:25
verses.text: He is refuted by what we have just said, and especially by the consideration that he takes the word "prophet" in a general sense; for he cannot show that any of the prophets baptized.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 13:26
verses.text: He adds, not incorrectly, that the Pharisees put the question from malice, and not from a desire to learn.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:1
verses.text: Comparison of the Statements of the Four Evangelists Respecting John the Baptist, the Prophecies Regarding Him, His Addresses to the Multitude and to the Pharisees, Etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:2
verses.text: We deem it necessary to compare with the expression of the passage we are considering the similar expressions found elsewhere in the Gospels.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:3
verses.text: This we shall continue to do point by point to the end of this work, so that terms which appear to disagree may be shown to be in harmony, and that the peculiar meanings present in each may be explained.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:4
verses.text: This we shall do in the present passage.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:5
verses.text: The words, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord," are placed by John, who was a disciple, in the mouth of the Baptist.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:6
verses.text: In Mark, on the other hand, the same words are recorded at the beginning of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, in accordance with the Scripture of Isaiah, as thus: "The beginning of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, as it is written in Isaiah the prophet, Behold, I send My messenger before thy face, who shall prepare thy way before thee.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:7
verses.text: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:8
verses.text: Now the words, "Make straight the way of the Lord," added by John, are not found in the prophet.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:9
verses.text: Perhaps John was seeking to compress the "Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight the paths of our God," and so wrote, "Make straight the way of the Lord;" while Mark combined two prophecies spoken by two different prophets in different places, and made one prophecy out of them, "As it is written in Isaiah the prophet, Behold I send My messenger before thy face, who shall prepare thy way.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:10
verses.text: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:11
verses.text: The words, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness," are written immediately after the narrative of Hezekiah's recovery from his sickness, while the words, "Behold I send My messenger before thy face," are written by Malachi.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:12
verses.text: What John does here, abbreviating the text he quotes, we find done by Mark also at another point.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:13
verses.text: For while the words of the prophet are, "Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight the paths of our God," Mark writes, "Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:14
verses.text: And John practises a similar abbreviation in the text, "Behold I send My messenger before thy face, who shall prepare thy way before thee," when he does not add the words "before thee," as in the original.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:15
verses.text: Coming now to the statement, "They were sent from the Pharisees and they asked Him," we have been led by our examination of the passage to prefix the enquiry of the Pharisees—which Matthew does not mention—to the occurrence recorded in Matthew, when John saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, and said to them, "Ye generations of vipers," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:16
verses.text: For the natural sequence is that they should first enquire and then come.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:17
verses.text: And we have to observe how, when Matthew reports that there went out to John Jerusalem and all Judaea, and all the region round about Jordan, to be baptized by him in Jordan, confessing their sins, it was not these people who heard from the Baptist any word of rebuke or refutation, but only those many Pharisees and Sadducees whom he saw coming.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:18
verses.text: They it was who were greeted with the address, "Ye offspring of vipers," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:19
verses.text: Mark, again, does not record any words of reproof as having been used by John to those who came to him, being all the country of Judaea and all of them of Jerusalem, who were baptized by him in the Jordan and confessed their sins.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:20
verses.text: This is because Mark does not mention the Pharisees and Sadducees as having come to John.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:21
verses.text: A further circumstance which we must mention is that both Matthew and Mark state that, in the one case, all Jerusalem and all Judaea, and the whole region round about Jordan, in the other, the whole land of Judaea and all they of Jerusalem, were baptized, confessing their sins; but when Matthew introduces the Pharisees and Sadducees as coming to the baptism, he does not say that they confessed their sins, and this might very likely and very naturally be the reason why they were addressed as "offspring of vipers".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:22
verses.text: Do not suppose, reader, that there is anything improper in our adducing in our discussion of the question of those who were sent from the Pharisees and put questions to John, the parallel passages from the other Gospels too.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:23
verses.text: For if we have indicated the proper connection between the enquiry of the Pharisees, recorded by the disciple John, and their baptism which is found in Matthew, we could scarcely avoid inquiring into the passages in question, nor recording the observations made on them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:24
verses.text: Luke, like Mark, remembers the passage, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness," but he for his part treats it as follows: "The word of God came unto John, the son of Zacharias, in the wilderness.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:25
verses.text: And he came into all the region round about Jordan preaching the baptism of repentance unto remission of sins; as it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet, The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:26
verses.text: Luke, however, added the continuation of the prophecy: "Every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be brought low, and the crooked shall become straight, and the rough ways smooth, and all flesh shall see the salvation of God".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:27
verses.text: He writes, like Mark, "Make His ways straight;" curtailing, as we saw before, the text, "Make straight the ways of our God".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:28
verses.text: In the phrase, "And all the crooked shall become straight," he leaves out the "all," and the word "straight" he converts from a plural into a singular.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:29
verses.text: Instead of the phrase, moreover, "The rough land into a plain," he gives, "The rough ways into smooth ways," and he leaves out "And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed," and gives what follows, "And all flesh shall see the salvation of God".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:30
verses.text: These observations are of use as showing how the evangelists are accustomed to abbreviate the sayings of the prophets.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:31
verses.text: It has also to be observed that the speech, "Offspring of vipers," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:32
verses.text: , is said by Matthew to have been spoken to the Pharisees and Sadducees when coming to baptism, they being a different set of people from those who confessed their sins, and to whom no words of this kind were spoken.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:33
verses.text: With Luke, on the contrary, these words were addressed to the multitudes who came out to be baptized by John, and there were not two divisions of those who were baptized, as we found in Matthew.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:34
verses.text: But Matthew, as the careful observer will see, does not speak of the multitudes in the way of praise, and he probably means the Baptist's address, Offspring of vipers, etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:35
verses.text: , to be understood as addressed to them also.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:36
verses.text: Another point is, that to the Pharisees and Sadducees he says, "Bring forth a fruit," in the singular, "worthy of repentance," but to the multitudes he uses the plural, "Bring forth fruits worthy of repentance".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:37
verses.text: Perhaps the Pharisees are required to yield the special fruit of repentance, which is no other than the Son and faith in Him, while the multitudes, who have not even a beginning of good things, are asked for all the fruits of repentance, and so the plural is used to them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:38
verses.text: Further, it is said to the Pharisees, "Think not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham for our father".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:39
verses.text: For the multitudes now have a beginning, appearing as they do to be introduced into the divine Word, and to approach the truth; and thus they begin to say within themselves, "We have Abraham for our father".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:40
verses.text: The Pharisees, on the contrary, are not beginning to this, but have long held it to be so.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:41
verses.text: But both classes see John point to the stones aforesaid and declare that even from these children can be raised up to Abraham, rising up out of unconsciousness and deadness.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:42
verses.text: And observe how it is said to the Pharisees, according to the word of the prophet, "Ye have eaten false fruit," and they have false fruit,—"Every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire," while to the multitudes which do not bear fruit at all, "Every tree which bringeth not forth fruit is hewn down".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:43
verses.text: For that which has no fruit at all has not good fruit, and, therefore, it is worthy to be hewn down.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:44
verses.text: But that which bears fruit has by no means good fruit, whence it also calls for the axe to lay it low.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:45
verses.text: But, if we look more closely into this about the fruit, we shall find that it is impossible that that which has just begun to be cultivated, even should it not prove fruitless, should bear the first good fruits.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:46
verses.text: The husbandman is content that the tree just coming into cultivation should bear him at first such fruits as it may; afterwards, when he has pruned and trained it according to his art, he will receive, not the fruits it chanced to bear at first, but good fruits.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:47
verses.text: The law itself favours this interpretation, for it says that the planter is to wait for three years, having the trees pruned and not eating the fruit of them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:48
verses.text: "Three years," it says, "the fruit shall be unpurified to you, and shall not be eaten, but in the fourth year all the fruit shall be holy, for giving praise unto the Lord".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:49
verses.text: This explains how the word "good" is omitted from the address to the multitudes, "Every tree, therefore, which bears not fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:50
verses.text: The tree which goes on bearing such fruit as it did at first, is a tree which does not bear good fruit, and is, therefore, cut down, and cast into the fire, since, when the three years have passed and the fourth comes round, it does not bear good fruit, for praise unto the Lord.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:51
verses.text: In thus adducing the passages from the other Gospels I may appear to be digressing, but I cannot think it useless, or without bearing on our present subject.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:52
verses.text: For the Pharisees send to John, after the priests and levites who came from Jerusalem, men who came to ask him who he was, and enquire, Why baptizest thou then, if thou be not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet? After making this enquiry they straightway come for baptism, as Matthew records, and then they hear words suited to their quackery and hypocrisy.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:53
verses.text: But the words addressed to them were very similar to those spoken to the multitudes, and hence the necessity to look carefully at both speeches, and to compare them together.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:54
verses.text: It was while we were so engaged that various points arose in the sequence of the matter, which we had to consider.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:55
verses.text: To what has been said we must add the following.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:56
verses.text: We find mention made in John of two orders of persons sending: the one, that of the Jews from Jerusalem sending priests and levites; the other, that of the Pharisees who want to know why he baptizes.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:57
verses.text: And we found that, after the enquiry, the Pharisees present themselves for baptism.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:58
verses.text: May it not be that the Jews, who had sent the earlier mission from Jerusalem, received John's words before those who sent the second mission, namely, the Pharisees, and hence arrived before them? For Jerusalem and all Judaea, and, in consequence, the whole region round about Jordan, were being baptized by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins; or, as Mark says, "There went out to him the whole land of Judaea, and all they of Jerusalem, and were baptized of him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:59
verses.text: Now, neither does Matthew introduce the Pharisees and Sadducees, to whom the words, "Offspring of vipers," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:60
verses.text: , are addressed; nor does Luke introduce the multitudes who meet with the same rebuke, as confessing their sins.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:61
verses.text: And the question may be raised how, if the whole city of Jerusalem, and the whole of Judaea, and the whole region round about Jordan, were baptized of John in Jordan, the Saviour could say, "John the Baptist came neither eating nor drinking, and ye say he hath a devil;" and how could He say to those who asked Him, "By what authority doest thou these things? I also will ask you one word, which if ye tell me, I also will tell you by what authority I do these things.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:62
verses.text: The baptism of John, whence was it? from heaven or of men? And they reason, and say, If we shall say, From heaven, He will say, Why did ye not believe him?" The solution of the difficulty is this.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:63
verses.text: The Pharisees, addressed by John, as we saw before, with his "Offspring of vipers," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:64
verses.text: , came to the baptism, without believing in him, probably because they feared the multitudes, and, with their accustomed hypocrisy towards them, deemed it right to undergo the washing, so as not to appear hostile to those who did so.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:65
verses.text: Their belief was, then, that he derived his baptism from men, and not from heaven, but, on account of the multitude, lest they should be stoned, they are afraid to say what they think.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:66
verses.text: Thus there is no contradiction between the Saviour's speech to the Pharisees and the narratives in the Gospels about the multitudes who frequented John's baptism.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 14:67
verses.text: It was part of the effrontery of the Pharisees that they declared John to have a devil, as, also, that they declared Jesus to have performed His wonderful works by Beelzebub, the prince of the devils.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:1
verses.text: How the Baptist Answers the Question of the Pharisees and Exalts the Nature of Christ.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:2
verses.text: Of the Shoe-Latchet Which He is Unable to Untie.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:3
verses.text: John answered them, saying, "I baptize with water, but in the midst of you standeth one whom ye know not, even He who cometh after me, the latchet of whose shoe I am not worthy to unloose".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:4
verses.text: Heracleon considers that John's answers to those sent by the Pharisees refer not to what they asked, but to what he wished, not observing that he accuses the prophet of a want of manners, by making him, when asked about one thing, answer about another; for this is a fault to be guarded against in conversation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:5
verses.text: We assert, on the contrary, that the reply accurately takes up the question.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:6
verses.text: It is asked, "Why baptizest thou then, if thou art not the Christ?" And what other answer could be given to this than to show that his baptism was in its nature a bodily thing? I, he says, "baptize with water;" this is his answer to, "Why baptizest thou".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:7
verses.text: And to the second part of their question, "If thou art not the Christ," he answers by exalting the superior nature of Christ, that He has such virtue as to be invisible in His deity, though present to every man and extending over the whole universe.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:8
verses.text: This is what is indicated in the words, "There standeth one among you".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:9
verses.text: The Pharisees, moreover, though expecting the advent of Christ, saw nothing in Him of such a nature as John speaks of; they believed Him to be simply a perfect and holy man.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:10
verses.text: John, therefore, rebukes their ignorance of His superiority, and adds to the words, "There standeth one among you," the clause, "whom ye know not".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:11
verses.text: And, lest any one should suppose the invisible One who extends to every man, or, indeed, to the whole world, to be a different person from Him who became man, and appeared upon the earth and conversed with men, he adds to the words, "There standeth one among you whom you know not," the further words, "Who cometh after me," that is, He who is to be manifested after me.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:12
verses.text: By whose surpassing excellence he well understood that his own nature was far surpassed, though some doubted whether he might be the Christ; and, therefore, desiring to show how far he is from attaining to the greatness of the Christ, that no one should think of him beyond what he sees or hears of him, he goes on: "The latchet of whose shoe I am not worthy to unloose".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 15:13
verses.text: By which he conveys, as in a riddle, that he is not fit to solve and to explain the argument about Christ's assuming a human body, an argument tied up and hidden (like a shoe-tie) to those who do not understand it,—so as to say anything worthy of such an advent, compressed, as it was, into so short a space.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:1
verses.text: Comparison of John's Testimony to Jesus in the Different Gospels.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:2
verses.text: It may not be out of place, as we are examining the text, "I baptize with water," to compare the parallel utterances of the evangelists with this of John.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:3
verses.text: Matthew reports that the Baptist, when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, after the words of rebuke which we have already studied, went on: "I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance; but He that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear; He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:4
verses.text: This agrees with the words in John, in which the Baptist declares himself to those sent by the Pharisees, on the subject of his baptizing with water.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:5
verses.text: Mark, again, says, "John preached, saying, There cometh after me He that is mightier than I, the latchet of whose shoes I am not worthy to stoop down and unloose.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:6
verses.text: I baptized you with water, but He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 16:7
verses.text: And Luke says that, as the people were in expectation, and all were reasoning in their hearts concerning John, whether haply he were the Christ, John answered them all, saying, "I indeed baptize you with water; but there cometh one mightier than I, whose shoe-latchet I am not worthy to unloose; He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:1
verses.text: Of the Testimony of John to Jesus in Matthew's Gospel,  These, then, are the parallel passages of the four; let us try to see as clearly as we can what is the purport of each and wherein they differ from each other.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:2
verses.text: And we will begin with Matthew, who is reported by tradition to have published his Gospel before the others, to the Hebrews, those, namely, of the circumcision who believed.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:3
verses.text: I, he says, baptize you with water unto repentance, purifying you, as it were, and turning you away from evil courses and calling you to repentance; for I am come to make ready for the Lord a people prepared for Him, and by my baptism of repentance to prepare the ground for Him who is to come after me, and who will thus benefit you much more effectively and powerfully than my strength could.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:4
verses.text: For His baptism is not that of the body only; He fills the penitent with the Holy Ghost, and His diviner fire does away with everything material and consumes everything that is earthy, not only from him who admits it to his life, but even from him who hears of it from those who have it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:5
verses.text: So much stronger than I is He who is coming after me, that I am not able to bear even the outskirts of the powers round Him which are furthest from Him (they are not open and exposed, so that any one could see them), nor even to bear those who support them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:6
verses.text: I know not of which I should speak.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:7
verses.text: Should I speak of my own great weakness, which is not able to bear even these things about Christ which in comparison with the greater things in Him are least, or should I speak of His transcendent Deity, greater than all the world? If I who have received such grace, as to be thought worthy of prophecy predicting my arrival in this human life, in the words, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness," and "Behold I send my messenger before thy face;" if I whose birth Gabriel who stands before God announced to my father so advanced in years, so much against his expectation, I at whose name Zacharias recovered his voice and was enabled to use it to prophesy, I to whom my Lord bears witness that among them that are born of women there is none greater than I, I am not able so much as to bear His shoes! And if not His shoes, what can be said about His garments? Who is so great as to be able to guard His coat? Who can suppose that He can understand the meaning contained in His tunic which is without seam from the top because it is woven throughout? It is to be observed that while the four represent John as declaring himself to have come to baptize with water, Matthew alone adds the words "to repentance," teaching that the benefit of baptism is connected with the intention of the baptized person; to him who repents it is salutary, but to him who comes to it without repentance it will turn to greater condemnation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:8
verses.text: And here we must note that as the wonderful works done by the Saviour in the cures He wrought, which are symbolical of those who at any time are set free by the word of God from any sickness or disease, though they were done to the body and brought a bodily relief, yet also called those who were benefited by them to an exercise of faith, so the washing with water which is symbolic of the soul cleansing herself from every stain of wickedness, is no less in itself to him who yields himself to the divine power of the invocation of the Adorable Trinity, the beginning and source of divine gifts; for "there are diversities of gifts".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:9
verses.text: This view receives confirmation from the narrative recorded in the Acts of the Apostles, which shows the Spirit to have descended so manifestly on those who receive baptism, after the water had prepared the way for him in those who properly approached the rite.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:10
verses.text: Simon Magus, astonished at what he saw, desired to receive from Peter this gift, but though it was a good thing he desired, he thought to attain it by the mammon of unrighteousness.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:11
verses.text: We next remark in passing that the baptism of John was inferior to the baptism of Jesus which was given through His disciples.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:12
verses.text: Those persons in the Acts who were baptized to John's baptism and who had not heard if there was any Holy Ghost are baptized over again by the Apostle.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:13
verses.text: Regeneration did not take place with John, but with Jesus through His disciples it does so, and what is called the laver of regeneration takes place with renewal of the Spirit; for the Spirit now comes in addition since it comes from God and is over and above the water and does not come to all after the water.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 17:14
verses.text: So far, then, our examination of the statements in the Gospel according to Matthew.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:1
verses.text: Of the Testimony in Mark.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:2
verses.text: What is Meant by the Saviour's Shoes and by Untying His Shoe-Latchets.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:3
verses.text: Now let us consider what is stated by Mark.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:4
verses.text: Mark's account of John's preaching agrees with the other.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:5
verses.text: The words are, "There cometh after me He that is mightier than I," which amounts to the same thing as "He that cometh after me is mightier than I".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:6
verses.text: There is a difference, however, in what follows, "The latchets of His shoes I am not worthy to stoop down and untie".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:7
verses.text: For it is one thing to bear a person's shoes,—they must, it is evident, have been untied already from the feet of the wearer,—and it is another thing to stoop down and untie the latchet of his shoes.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:8
verses.text: And it follows, since believers cannot think that either of the Evangelists made any mistake or misrepresentation, that the Baptist must have made these two utterances at different times and have meant them to express different things.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:9
verses.text: It is not the case, as some suppose.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:10
verses.text: that the reports refer to the same incident and turned out differently because of a looseness of memory as to some of the facts or words.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:11
verses.text: Now it is a great thing to bear the shoes of Jesus, a great thing to stoop down to the bodily features of His mission, to that which took place in some lower region, so as to contemplate His image in the lower sphere, and to untie each difficulty connected with the mystery of His incarnation, such being as it were His shoe-latchets.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:12
verses.text: For the fetter of obscurity is one as the key of knowledge also is one; not even He who is greatest among those born of women is sufficient of Himself to loose such things or to open them, for He who tied and locked at first, He also grants to whom He will to loose His shoe-latchet and to unlock what He has shut.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:13
verses.text: If the passage about the shoes has a mystic meaning we ought not to scorn to consider it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:14
verses.text: Now I consider that the inhumanisation when the Son of God assumes flesh and bones is one of His shoes, and that the other is the descent to Hades, whatever that Hades be, and the journey with the Spirit to the prison.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:15
verses.text: As to the descent into Hades, we read in the sixteenth Psalm, "Thou wilt not leave my soul in Hades," and as for the journey in prison with the Spirit we read in Peter in his Catholic Epistle, "Put to death," he says, "in the flesh, but quickened in the Spirit; in which also He went and preached unto the spirits in prison, which at one time were disobedient, when the long-suffering of God once waited in the days of Noah while the ark was a preparing".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:16
verses.text: He, then, who is able worthily to set forth the meaning of these two journeys is able to untie the latchet of the shoes of Jesus; he, bending down in his mind and going with Jesus as He goes down into Hades, and descending from heaven and the mysteries of Christ's deity to the advent He of necessity made with us when He took on man (as His shoes).

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:17
verses.text: Now He who put on man also put on the dead, for "for this end Jesus both died and revived, that He might be Lord both of dead and living".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:18
verses.text: This is why He put on both living and dead, that is, the inhabitants of the earth and those of Hades, that He might be the Lord of both dead and living.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 18:19
verses.text: Who, then, is able to stoop down and untie the latchet of such shoes, and having untied them not to let them drop, but by the second faculty he has received to take them up and bear them, by bearing the meaning of them in his memory?.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 19

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 19:1
verses.text: Luke and John Suggest that One May Loose the Shoe-Latchets of the Logos Without Stooping Down.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 19:2
verses.text: We must not, however, omit to ask how it comes that Luke and John give the speech without the phrase "to stoop down".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 19:3
verses.text: He, perhaps, who stoops down may be held to unloose in the sense which we have stated.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 19:4
verses.text: On the other hand, it may be that one who fixes his eyes on the height of the exaltation of the Logos, may find the loosing of those shoes which when one is seeking them seem to be bound, so that He also looses those shoes which are separable from the Logos, and beholds the Logos divested of inferior things, as He is, the Son of God.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:1
verses.text: The Difference Between Not Being "Sufficient" And Not Being "Worthy".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:2
verses.text: John records that the Baptist said he was not worthy, Mark that he was not sufficient, and these two are not the same.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:3
verses.text: One who was not worthy might yet be sufficient, and one who was worthy might not be sufficient.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:4
verses.text: For even if it be the case that gifts are bestowed to profit withal and not merely according to the proportion of faith, yet it would seem to be the part of a God who loves men and who sees before what harm must come from the rise of self-opinion or conceit, not to bestow sufficiency even on the worthy.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:5
verses.text: But it belongs to the goodness of God by conferring bounties to conquer the object of His bounty, taking in advance him who is destined to be worthy, and adorning him even before he becomes worthy with sufficiency, so that after his sufficiency he may come to be worthy; he is not first to be worthy and then to anticipate the giver and take His gifts before the time and so arrive at being sufficient.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:6
verses.text: Now with the three the Baptist says he is not sufficient, while in John he says he is not worthy.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:7
verses.text: But it may be that he who formerly declared that he was not sufficient became sufficient afterwards, even though perhaps he was not worthy, or again that while he was saying he was not worthy, and was in fact not worthy, he arrived at being worthy, unless one should say that human nature can never come to perform worthily this loosing or this bearing, and that John, therefore, says truly that he never became sufficient to loose the latchets of the Saviour's shoes, nor worthy of it either.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 20:8
verses.text: However much we take into our minds there are still left things not yet understood; for, as we read in the wisdom of Jesus, son of Sirach, "When a man hath done, then he beginneth, and when he leaveth off, then he shall be doubtful".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:1
verses.text: The Fourth Gospel Speaks of Only One Shoe, the Others of Both.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:2
verses.text: The Significance of This.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:3
verses.text: As to the shoes, too, which are spoken of in the three Gospels, we have a question to consider; we must compare them with the single shoe named by the disciple John.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:4
verses.text: "I am not worthy," we read there, "to untie the latchet of His shoe".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:5
verses.text: Perhaps he was conquered by the grace of God, and received the gift of doing that which of himself he would not have been worthy to do, of untying, namely, the latchet of one of the shoes, namely, after he had seen the Saviour's sojourn among men, of which he bears witness.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:6
verses.text: But he did not know the things which were to follow, namely, whether Jesus was to come to that place also, to which he was to go after being beheaded in prison, or whether he was to look for another; and hence he alludes enigmatically to that doubt which was afterwards cleared up to us, and says, "I am not worthy to untie His shoe-latchet".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:7
verses.text: If any one considers this to be a superfluous speculation, he can combine in one the speech about the shoes and that about the shoe, as if John said, I am by no means worthy to loose His shoestring, not even at the beginning, the string of one of His shoes.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:8
verses.text: Or the following may be a way to combine what is said in the Four.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:9
verses.text: If John understands about Jesus' sojourn here, but is in doubt about the future, then he says with perfect truth that he is not worthy to loose the latchet of His shoes; for though he loosed that of one shoe, he did not loose both.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 21:10
verses.text: And on the other hand, what he says about the latchet of the shoe is quite true also; since as we saw he is still in doubt whether Jesus is He that was to come, or whether another is to be looked for, in that other region.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:1
verses.text: How the Word Stands in the Midst of Men Without Being Known of Them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:2
verses.text: As for the saying, "There standeth one among you whom you know not," we are led by it to consider the Son of God, the Word, by whom all things were made, since He exists in substance throughout the underlying nature of things, being the same as wisdom.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:3
verses.text: For He permeated, from the beginning, all creation, so that what is made at any time should be made through Him, and that it might be always true of anything soever, that "All things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made that was made;" and this saying also, "By wisdom didst thou make them all".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:4
verses.text: Now, if He permeates all creation, then He is also in those questioners who ask, "Why baptizest thou, if thou art not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet?" In the midst of them stands the Word, who is the same and steadfast, being everywhere established by the Father.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:5
verses.text: Or the words, "There standeth among you," may be understood to say, In the midst of you men, because you are reasonable beings, stands He who is proved by Scripture to be the sovereign principle in the midst of every body, and so to be present in your heart.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:6
verses.text: Those, therefore, who have the Word in the midst of them, but who do not consider His nature, nor from what spring and principle He came, nor how He gave them the nature they have, these, while having Him in the midst of them, know Him not.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:7
verses.text: But John knew Him: for the words, "Whom you know not," used in reproach to the Pharisees, show that he well knew the Word whom they did not know.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:8
verses.text: And the Baptist, therefore, knowing Him, saw Him coming after himself, who was now in the midst of them, that is to say, dwelling after him and the teaching he gave in his baptism, in those who, according to reason (or the Word), submitted to that purifying rite.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:9
verses.text: The word "after," however, has not the same meaning here as it has when Jesus commands us to come "after" Him; for in this case we are bidden to go after Him, so that, treading in His steps, we may come to the Father; but in the other case, the meaning is that after the teachings of John (since "He came in order that all men through Him might believe"), the Word dwells with those who have prepared themselves, purified as they are by the lesser words for the perfect Word.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:10
verses.text: Firstly, then, stands the Father, being without any turning or change; and then stands also His Word, always carrying on His work of salvation, and even when He is in the midst of men, not comprehended, and not even seen.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 22:11
verses.text: He stands, also, teaching, and inviting all to drink from His abundant spring, for "Jesus stood and cried, saying, If any man thirst, let him come unto Me and drink".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:1
verses.text: Heracleon's View of This Utterance of John the Baptist, and Interpretation of the Shoe of Jesus.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:2
verses.text: But Heracleon declares the words, "There standeth one among you," to be equivalent to "He is already here, and He is in the world and in men, and He is already manifest to you all".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:3
verses.text: By this He does away with the meaning which is also present in the words, that the Word had permeated the whole world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:4
verses.text: For we must say to him, When is He not present, and when is He not in the world? Does not this Gospel say, "He was in the world, and the world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:5
verses.text: And this is why those to whom the Logos is He "whom you know not," do not know Him: they have never gone out of the world, but the world does not know Him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:6
verses.text: But at what time did He cease to be among men? Was He not in Isaiah, when He said, "The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because He hath anointed me," and "I became manifest to those who sought me not".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:7
verses.text: Let them say, too, if He was not in David when he said, not from himself, "But I was established by Him a king in Zion His holy hill," and the other words spoken in the Psalms in the person of Christ.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:8
verses.text: And why should I go over the details of this proof, truly they are hard to be numbered, when I can show quite clearly that He was always in men? And that is enough to show Heracleon's interpretation of "There standeth in the midst of you," to be unsound, when he says it is equivalent to "He is already here, and He is in the world and in men".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:9
verses.text: We are disposed to agree with him when he says that the words, "Who cometh after me," show John to be the forerunner of Christ, for he is in fact a kind of servant running before his master.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:10
verses.text: The words, however, "Whose shoe-latchet I am not worthy to unloose," receive much too simple an interpretation when it is said that "in these words the Baptist confesses that he is not worthy even of the least honourable ministration to Christ".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:11
verses.text: After this interpretation he adds, not without sense, "I am not worthy that for my sake He should come down from His greatness and should take flesh as His footgear, concerning which I am not able to give any explanation or description, nor to unloose the arrangement of it".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:12
verses.text: In understanding the world by his shoe, Heracleon shows some largeness of mind, but immediately after he verges on impiety in declaring that all this is to be understood of that person whom John here has in his mind.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:13
verses.text: For he considers that it is the demiurge of the world who confesses by these words that he is a lesser person than the Christ; and this is the height of impiety.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:14
verses.text: For the Father who sent Him, He who is the God of the living as Jesus Himself testifies, of Abraham and of Isaac and of Jacob, and He who is greater than heaven and earth for the reason that He is the Maker of them, He also alone is good and is greater than He who was sent by Him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:15
verses.text: And even if, as we said, Heracleon's idea was a lofty one, that the whole world was the shoe of Jesus, yet I think we ought not to agree with him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:16
verses.text: For how can it be harmonized with such a view, that "Heaven is My throne and the earth My footstool," a testimony which Jesus accepts as said of the Father? "Swear not by heaven," He says, "for it is God's throne, nor by the earth, for it is the footstool of His feet".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:17
verses.text: How, if he takes the whole world to be the shoe of Jesus, can he also accept the text, "Do not I fill heaven and earth?" saith the Lord.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:18
verses.text: It is also worth while to enquire, whether as the Word and wisdom permeated the whole world, and as the Father was in the Son, the words are to be understood as above or in this way, that He who first of all was girded about with the whole creation, in addition to the Son's being in Him, granted to the Saviour, as being second after Him and being God the Word, to pervade the whole creation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:19
verses.text: To those who have it in them to take note of the uninterrupted movement of the great heaven, how it carries with it from East to West so great a multitude of stars, to them most of all it will seem needful to enquire what that force is, how great and of what nature, which is present in the whole world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 23:20
verses.text: For to pronounce that force to be other than the Father and the Son, that perhaps might be inconsistent with piety.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:1
verses.text: The Name of the Place Where John Baptized is Not Bethany, as in Most Copies, But Bethabara.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:2
verses.text: Proof of This.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:3
verses.text: Similarly "Gergesa" Should Be Read for "Gerasa," In the Story of the Swine.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:4
verses.text: Attention is to Be Paid to the Proper Names in Scripture, Which are Often Written Inaccurately, and are of Importance for Interpretation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:5
verses.text: "These things were done in Bethabara, beyond Jordan, where John was baptizing".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:6
verses.text: We are aware of the reading which is found in almost all the copies, "These things were done in Bethany".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:7
verses.text: This appears, moreover, to have been the reading at an earlier time; and in Heracleon we read "Bethany".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:8
verses.text: We are convinced, however, that we should not read "Bethany," but "Bethabara".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:9
verses.text: We have visited the places to enquire as to the footsteps of Jesus and His disciples, and of the prophets.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:10
verses.text: Now, Bethany, as the same evangelist tells us, was the town of Lazarus, and of Martha and Mary; it is fifteen stadia from Jerusalem, and the river Jordan is about a hundred and eighty stadia distant from it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:11
verses.text: Nor is there any other place of the same name in the neighbourhood of the Jordan, but they say that Bethabara is pointed out on the banks of the Jordan, and that John is said to have baptized there.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:12
verses.text: The etymology of the name, too, corresponds with the baptism of him who made ready for the Lord a people prepared for Him; for it yields the meaning "House of preparation," while Bethany means "House of obedience".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:13
verses.text: Where else was it fitting that he should baptize, who was sent as a messenger before the face of the Christ, to prepare His way before Him, but at the House of preparation? And what more fitting home for Mary, who chose the good part, which was not taken away from her, and for Martha, who was cumbered for the reception of Jesus, and for their brother, who is called the friend of the Saviour, than Bethany, the House of obedience? Thus we see that he who aims at a complete understanding of the Holy Scriptures must not neglect the careful examination of the proper names in it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:14
verses.text: In the matter of proper names the Greek copies are often incorrect, and in the Gospels one might be misled by their authority.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:15
verses.text: The transaction about the swine, which were driven down a steep place by the demons and drowned in the sea, is said to have taken place in the country of the Gerasenes.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:16
verses.text: Now, Gerasa is a town of Arabia, and has near it neither sea nor lake.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:17
verses.text: And the Evangelists would not have made a statement so obviously and demonstrably false; for they were men who informed themselves carefully of all matters connected with Judaea.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:18
verses.text: But in a few copies we have found, "into the country of the Gadarenes;" and, on this reading, it is to be stated that Gadara is a town of Judaea, in the neighbourhood of which are the well-known hot springs, and that there is no lake there with overhanging banks, nor any sea.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:19
verses.text: But Gergesa, from which the name Gergesenes is taken, is an old town in the neighbourhood of the lake now called Tiberias, and on the edge of it there is a steep place abutting on the lake, from which it is pointed out that the swine were cast down by the demons.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:20
verses.text: Now, the meaning of Gergesa is "dwelling of the casters-out," and it contains a prophetic reference to the conduct towards the Saviour of the citizens of those places, who "besought Him to depart out of their coasts".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:21
verses.text: The same inaccuracy with regard to proper names is also to be observed in many passages of the law and the prophets, as we have been at pains to learn from the Hebrews, comparing our own copies with theirs which have the confirmation of the versions, never subjected to corruption, of Aquila and Theodotion and Symmachus.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:22
verses.text: We add a few instances to encourage students to pay more attention to such points.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:23
verses.text: One of the sons of Levi, the first, is called Geson in most copies, instead of Gerson.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:24
verses.text: His name is the same as that of the first-born of Moses; it was given appropriately in each case, both children being born, because of the sojourn in Egypt, in a strange land.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:25
verses.text: The second son of Juda, again, has with us the name Annan, but with the Hebrews Onan, "their labour".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:26
verses.text: Once more, in the departures of the children of Israel in Numbers, we find, "They departed from Sochoth and pitched in Buthan;" but the Hebrew, instead of Buthan, reads Aiman.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:27
verses.text: And why should I add more points like these, when any one who desires it can examine into the proper names and find out for himself how they stand? The place-names of Scripture are specially to be suspected where many of them occur in a catalogue, as in the account of the partition of the country in Joshua, and in the first Book of Chronicles from the beginning down to, say, the passage about Dan, and similarly in Ezra.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:28
verses.text: Names are not to be neglected, since indications may be gathered from them which help in the interpretation of the passages where they occur.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 24:29
verses.text: We cannot, however, leave our proper subject to examine in this place into the philosophy of names.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:1
verses.text: Jordan Means "Their Going Down".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:2
verses.text: Spiritual Meanings and Application of This.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:3
verses.text: Let us look at the words of the Gospel now before us.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:4
verses.text: "Jordan" means "their going down".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:5
verses.text: The name "Jared" is etymologically akin to it, if I may say so; it also yields the meaning "going down;" for Jared was born to Maleleel, as it is written in the Book of Enoch—if any one cares to accept that book as sacred—in the days when the sons of God came down to the daughters of men.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:6
verses.text: Under this descent some have supposed that there is an enigmatical reference to the descent of souls into bodies, taking the phrase "daughters of men" as a tropical expression for this earthly tabernacle.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:7
verses.text: Should this be so, what river will "their going down" be, to which one must come to be purified, a river going down, not with its own descent, but "theirs," that, namely, of men, what but our Saviour who separates those who received their lots from Moses from those who obtained their own portions through Jesus (Joshua)? His current, flowing in the descending stream, makes glad, as we find in the Psalms, the city of God, not the visible Jerusalem—for it has no river beside it—but the blameless Church of God, built on the foundation of the Apostles and Prophets, Christ Jesus our Lord being the chief corner-stone.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:8
verses.text: Under the Jordan, accordingly, we have to understand the Word of God who became flesh and tabernacled among us, Jesus who gives us as our inheritance the humanity which He assumed, for that is the head corner-stone, which being taken up into the deity of the Son of God, is washed by being so assumed, and then receives into itself the pure and guileless dove of the Spirit, bound to it and no longer able to fly away from it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:9
verses.text: For "Upon whomsoever," we read, "thou shalt see the Spirit descending and abiding upon Him, the same is He that baptizeth with the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:10
verses.text: Hence, he who receives the Spirit abiding on Jesus Himself is able to baptize those who come to him in that abiding Spirit.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:11
verses.text: But John baptizes beyond Jordan, in the regions verging on the outside of Judaea, in Bethabara, being the forerunner of Him who came to call not the righteous but sinners, and who taught that the whole have no need of a physician, but they that are sick.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 25:12
verses.text: For it is for forgiveness of sins that this washing is given.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:1
verses.text: The Story of Israel Crossing Jordan Under Joshua is Typical of Christian Things, and is Written for Our Instruction.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:2
verses.text: Now, it may very well be that some one not versed in the various aspects of the Saviour may stumble at the interpretation given above of the Jordan; because John says, "I baptize with water, but He that cometh after me is stronger than I; He shall baptize you with the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:3
verses.text: To this we reply that, as the Word of God in His character as something to be drunk is to one set of men water, and to another wine, making glad the heart of man, and to others blood, since it is said, "Except ye drink My blood, ye have no life in you," and as in His character as food He is variously conceived as living bread or as flesh, so also He, the same person, is baptism of water, and baptism of Holy Spirit and of fire, and to some, also, of blood.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:4
verses.text: It is of His last baptism, as some hold, that He speaks in the words, "I have a baptism to be baptized with, and how am I straitened till it be accomplished?" And it agrees with this that the disciple John speaks in his Epistle of the Spirit, and the water, and the blood, as being one.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:5
verses.text: And again He declares Himself to be the way and the door, but clearly He is not the door to those to whom He is the way, and He is no longer the way to those to whom He is the door.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:6
verses.text: All those, then, who are being initiated in the beginning of the oracles of God, and come to the voice of him who cries in the wilderness, "Make straight the way of the Lord," the voice which sounds beyond Jordan at the house of preparation, let them prepare themselves so that they may be in a state to receive the spiritual word, brought home to them by the enlightenment of the Spirit.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:7
verses.text: As we are now, as our subject requires, bringing together all that relates to the Jordan, let us look at the "river".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:8
verses.text: God, by Moses, carried the people through the Red Sea, making the water a wall for them on the right hand and on the left, and by Joshua He carried them through Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:9
verses.text: Now, Paul deals with this Scripture, and his warfare is not according to the flesh of it, for he knew that the law is spiritual in a spiritual sense.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:10
verses.text: And he shows us that he understood what is said about the passage of the Red Sea; for he says in his first Epistle to the Corinthians, "I would not, brethren, have you ignorant, how that our fathers were all under the cloud, and all passed through the sea, and were all baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea, and did all eat the same spiritual meat, and drink the same spiritual drink; for they drank of the spiritual rock which followed them, and the rock was Christ".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:11
verses.text: In the spirit of this passage let us also pray that we may receive from God to understand the spiritual meaning of Joshua's passage through Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:12
verses.text: Of it, also, Paul would have said, "I would not, brethren, have you ignorant, that all our fathers went through Jordan, and were all baptized into Jesus in the spirit and in the river".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:13
verses.text: And Joshua, who succeeded Moses, was a type of Jesus Christ, who succeeds the dispensation through the law, and replaces it by the preaching of the Gospel.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:14
verses.text: And even if those Paul speaks of were baptized in the cloud and in the sea, there is something harsh and salt in their baptism.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:15
verses.text: They are still in fear of their enemies, and crying to the Lord and to Moses, saying, "Because there were no graves in Egypt, hast thou brought us forth to slay us in the wilderness? Why hast thou dealt thus with us, to bring us forth out of Egypt?" But the baptism to Joshua, which takes place in quite sweet and drinkable water, is in many ways superior to that earlier one, religion having by this time grown clearer and assuming a becoming order.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:16
