verses.text: For the ark of the covenant of the Lord our God is carried in procession by the priests and levites, the people following the ministers of God, it, also, accepting the law of holiness.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:17
verses.text: For Joshua says to the people, "Sanctify yourselves against tomorrow; the Lord will do wonders among you".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:18
verses.text: And he commands the priests to go before the people with the ark of the covenant, wherein is plainly showed forth the mystery of the Father's economy about the Son, which is highly exalted by Him who gave the Son this office; "That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven and things on earth and things under the earth, and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:19
verses.text: This is pointed out by what we find in the book called Joshua, "In that day I will begin to exalt thee before the children of Israel".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:20
verses.text: And we hear our Lord Jesus saying to the children of Israel, "Come hither and hear the words of the Lord your God.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:21
verses.text: Hereby ye shall know that the living God is in (among) you;" for when we are baptized to Jesus, we know that the living God is in us.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:22
verses.text: And, in the former case, they kept the passover in Egypt, and then began their journey, but with Joshua, after crossing Jordan on the tenth day of the first month they pitched their camp in Galgala; for a sheep had to be procured before invitations could be issued to the banquet after Joshua's baptism.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:23
verses.text: Then the children of Israel, since the children of those who came out of Egypt had not received circumcision, were circumcised by Joshua with a very sharp stone; the Lord declares that He takes away the reproach of Egypt on the day of Joshua's baptism, when Joshua purified the children of Israel.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:24
verses.text: For it is written: "And the Lord said to Joshua, the son of Nun, This day have I taken away the reproach of Egypt from off you".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:25
verses.text: Then the children of Israel kept the passover on the fourteenth day of the month, with much greater gladness than in Egypt, for they ate unleavened bread of the corn of the holy land, and fresh food better than manna.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:26
verses.text: For when they received the land of promise God did not entertain them with scantier food, nor when such a one as Joshua was their leader do they get inferior bread.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:27
verses.text: This will be plain to him who thinks of the true holy land and of the Jerusalem above.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:28
verses.text: Hence it is written in this same Gospel: Your fathers did eat bread in the wilderness, and are dead; he that eateth of this bread shall live for ever.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:29
verses.text: For the manna, though it was given by God, yet was bread of travel, bread supplied to those still under discipline, well fitted for those who were under tutors and governors.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:30
verses.text: And the new bread Joshua managed to get from corn they cut in the country, in the land of promise, others having laboured and his disciples reaping,—that was bread more full of life, distributed as it was to those who, for their perfection, were able to receive the inheritance of their fathers.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:31
verses.text: Hence, he who is still under discipline to that bread may receive death as far as it is concerned, but he who has attained to the bread that follows that, eating it, shall live for ever.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 26:32
verses.text: All this has been added, not, I conceive, without appropriateness, to our study of the baptism at the Jordan, administered by John at Bethabara.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27:1
verses.text: Of Elijah and Elisha Crossing the Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27:2
verses.text: Another point which we must not fail to notice is that when Elijah was about to be taken up in a whirlwind, as if to heaven, he took his mantle and wrapped it together and smote the water, which was divided hither and thither, and they went over both of them, that is, he and Elisha.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27:3
verses.text: His baptism in the Jordan made him fitter to be taken up, for, as we showed before, Paul gives the name of baptism to such a remarkable passage through the water.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27:4
verses.text: And through this same Jordan Elisha receives, through Elijah, the gift he desired, saying, "Let a double portion of thy spirit be upon me".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 27:5
verses.text: What enabled him to receive this gift of the spirit of Elijah was, perhaps, that he had passed through Jordan twice, once with Elijah, and the second time, when, after receiving the mantle of Elijah, he smote the water and said, "Where is the God of Elijah, even He? And he smote the waters, and they were divided hither and thither".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:1
verses.text: Naaman the Syrian and the Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:2
verses.text: No Other Stream Has the Same Healing Power.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:3
verses.text: Should any one object to the expression "He smote the water," on account of the conclusion we arrived at above with respect to the Jordan, that it is a type of the Word who descended for us our descending, we rejoin that with the Apostle the rock is plainly said to be Christ, and that it is smitten twice with the rod, so that the people may drink of the spiritual rock which follows them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:4
verses.text: The "smiting" in this new difficulty is that of those who are fond of suggesting something that contradicts the conclusion even before they have learned what the question is which is in hand.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:5
verses.text: From such God sets us free, since, on the one hand, He gives us to drink when we are thirsty, and on the other He prepares for us, in the immense and trackless deep, a road to pass over, namely, by the dividing of His Word, since it is by the reason which distinguishes (divides) that most things are made plain to us.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:6
verses.text: But that we may receive the right interpretation about this Jordan, so good to drink, so full of grace, it may be of use to compare the cleansing of Naaman the Syrian from his leprosy, and what is said of the rivers of religion of the enemies of Israel.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:7
verses.text: It is recorded of Naaman that he came with horse and chariot, and stood at the door of the house of Elisha.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:8
verses.text: And Elisha sent a messenger to him, saying, "Go, wash seven times in the Jordan, and thy flesh shall come again unto thee, and thou shalt be cleansed".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:9
verses.text: Then Naaman is angry; he does not see that our Jordan is the cleanser of those who are impure from leprosy, from that impurity, and their restorer to health; it is the Jordan that does this, and not the prophet; the office of the prophet is to direct to the healing agency.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:10
verses.text: Naaman then says, not understanding the great mystery of the Jordan, "Behold, I said that he will certainly come out to me, and will call upon the name of the Lord his God, and lay his hand upon the place, and restore the leper".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:11
verses.text: For to put his hand on the leprosy and cleanse it is a work belonging to our Lord Jesus only; for when the leper appealed to Him with faith, saying, "If Thou wilt Thou canst make me clean," He not only said, "I will, be thou clean," but in addition to the word He touched him, and he was cleansed from his leprosy.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:12
verses.text: Naaman, then, is still in error, and does not see how far inferior other rivers are to the Jordan for the cure of the suffering; he extols the rivers of Damascus, Arbana, and Pharpha, saying, "Are not Arbana and Pharpha, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? Shall I not wash in them and be clean?" For as none is good but one, God the Father, so among rivers none is good but the Jordan, nor able to cleanse from his leprosy him who with faith washes his soul in Jesus.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:13
verses.text: And this, I suppose, is the reason why the Israelites are recorded to have wept when they sat by the rivers of Babylon and remembered Zion; those who are carried captive, on account of their wickedness, when they taste other waters after sacred Jordan, are led to remember with longing their own river of salvation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:14
verses.text: Therefore it is said of the rivers of Babylon, "There we sat down," clearly because they were unable to stand, "and wept".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:15
verses.text: And Jeremiah rebukes those who wish to drink the waters of Egypt, and desert the water which comes down from heaven, and is named from its so coming down—namely, the Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:16
verses.text: He says, "What hast thou to do with the way of Egypt, to drink the water of Geon, and to drink the water of the river," or, as it is in the Hebrew, "to drink the water of Sion".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 28:17
verses.text: Of which water we have now to speak.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:1
verses.text: The River of Egypt and Its Dragon, Contrasted with the Jordan.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:2
verses.text: But that the Spirit in the inspired Scriptures is not speaking mainly of rivers to be seen with the eyes, may be gathered from Ezekiel's prophecies against Pharaoh, king of Egypt: "Behold I am against thee, Pharaoh, king of Egypt, the great dragon, seated in the midst of rivers, who sayest, Mine are the rivers, and I made them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:3
verses.text: And I will put traps in thy jaws, and I will make the fishes of the river to stick to thy fins, and I will bring thee up from the midst of thy river, and all the fish of the river, and I will cast thee down quickly and all the fish of the river; thou shalt fall upon the face of thy land, and thou shalt not be gathered together, and thou shalt not be adorned".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:4
verses.text: For what real bodily dragon has ever been reported as having been seen in the material river of Egypt? But consider if the river of Egypt be not the dwelling of the dragon who is our enemy, who was not even able to kill the child Moses.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:5
verses.text: But as the dragon is in the river of Egypt, so is God in the river which makes glad the city of God; for the Father is in the Son.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:6
verses.text: Hence those who come to wash themselves in Him put away the reproach of Egypt, and become more fit to be restored.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:7
verses.text: They are cleansed from that foulest leprosy, receive a double portion of spiritual gifts, and are made ready to receive the Holy Spirit, since the spiritual dove does not light on any other stream.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:8
verses.text: Thus we have considered in a way more worthy of the sacred subject the Jordan and the purification that is in it, and Jesus being washed in it, and the house of preparation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 29:9
verses.text: Let us, then, draw from the river as much help as we require.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:1
verses.text: Of What John Learned from Jesus When Mary Visited Elisabeth in the Hill Country.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:2
verses.text: "The next day John seeth Jesus coming unto him".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:3
verses.text: The mother of Jesus had formerly, as soon as she conceived, stayed with the mother of John, also at that time with child, and the Former then communicated to the Formed with some exactness His own image, and caused him to be conformed to His glory.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:4
verses.text: And from this outward similarity it came that with those who did not distinguish between the image itself and that which was according to the image, John was thought to be Christ and Jesus was supposed to be John risen from the dead.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:5
verses.text: So now Jesus, after the testimonies of John to Him which we have examined, is Himself seen by the Baptist coming to him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:6
verses.text: It is to be noticed that on the former occasion, when the voice of Mary's salutation came to the ears of Elisabeth, the babe John leaped in the womb of his mother, who then received the Holy Spirit, as it were, from the ground.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:7
verses.text: For it came to pass, we read, "when Elisabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the babe leaped in her womb; and Elisabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit, and she lifted up her voice with a loud cry and said," etc.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:8
verses.text: On this occasion, similarly, John sees Jesus coming to him and says, "Behold the Lamb of God which taketh away the sin of the world".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:9
verses.text: For with regard to matters of great moment one is first instructed by hearing and afterwards one sees them with one's own eyes.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:10
verses.text: That John was helped to the shape he was to wear by the Lord who, still in the process of formation and in His mother's womb, approached Elisabeth, will be clear to any one who has grasped our proof that John is a voice but that Jesus is the Word, for when Elisabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit at the salutation of Mary there was a great voice in her, as the words themselves bear; for they say, "And she spake out with a loud voice".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:11
verses.text: Elisabeth, it is plain, did this, "and she spake".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:12
verses.text: For the voice of Mary's salutation coming to the ears of Elisabeth filled John with itself; hence John leaps, and his mother becomes, as it were, the mouth of her son and a prophetess, crying out with a loud voice and saying, "Blessed art thou among women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:13
verses.text: Now we see clearly how it was with Mary's hasty journey to the hill country, and her entrance into the house of Zacharias, and the greeting with which she salutes Elisabeth; it was that she might communicate some of the power she derived from Him she had conceived, to John, yet in his mother's womb, and that John too might communicate to his mother some of the prophetic grace which had come to him, that all these things were done.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:14
verses.text: And most rightly was it in the hill country that these transactions took place, since no great thing can be entertained by those who are low and may be thence called valleys.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:15
verses.text: Here, then, after the testimonies of John,—the first, when he cried and spoke about His deity; the second, addressed to the priests and levites who were sent by the Jews from Jerusalem; and the third, in answer to the sharper questions of those from the Pharisees,—Jesus is seen by the witness-bearer coming to him while he is still advancing and growing better.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:16
verses.text: This advance and improvement is symbolically indicated in the phrase, "On the morrow".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:17
verses.text: For Jesus came in the consequent illumination, as it were, and on the day after what had preceded, not only known as standing in the midst even of those who knew Him not, but now plainly seen advancing to him who had formerly made such declarations about Him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:18
verses.text: On the first day the testimonies take place, and on the second Jesus comes to John.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:19
verses.text: On the third John, standing with two of his disciples and looking upon Jesus as He walked, said, "Behold the Lamb of God," thus urging those who were there to follow the Son of God.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:20
verses.text: On the fourth day, too, He was minded to go forth into Galilee, and He who came forth to seek that which was lost finds Philip and says to him, "Follow Me".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:21
verses.text: And on that day, after the fourth, which is the sixth from the beginning of those we have enumerated, the marriage takes place in Cana of Galilee, which we shall have to consider when we get to the passage.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 30:22
verses.text: Note this, too, that Mary being the greater comes to Elisabeth, who is the less, and the Son of God comes to the Baptist; which should encourage us to render help without delay to those who are in a lower position, and to cultivate for ourselves a moderate station.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:1
verses.text: Of the Conversation Between John and Jesus at the Baptism, Recorded by Matthew Only.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:2
verses.text: John the disciple does not tell us where the Saviour comes from to John the Baptist, but we learn this from Matthew, who writes: "Then cometh Jesus from Galilee to Jordan to John, to be baptized of him".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:3
verses.text: And Mark adds the place in Galilee; he says, "And it came to pass in those days, that Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized by John in Jordan".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:4
verses.text: Luke does not mention the place Jesus came from, but on the other hand he tells us what we do not learn from the others, that immediately after the baptism, as He was coming up, heaven was opened to Him, and the Holy Spirit descended on Him in bodily form like a dove.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:5
verses.text: Again, it is Matthew alone who tells us of John's preventing the Lord, saying to the Saviour, "I have need to be baptized of Thee, and comest Thou to me?" None of the others added this after Matthew, so that they might not be saying just the same as he.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 31:6
verses.text: And what the Lord rejoined, "Suffer it now, for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness," this also Matthew alone recorded.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:1
verses.text: John Calls Jesus a "Lamb".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:2
verses.text: Why Does He Name This Animal Specially? Of the Typology of the Sacrifices, Generally.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:3
verses.text: "And he sayeth, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:4
verses.text: There were five animals which were brought to the altar, three that walk and two that fly; and it seems to be worth asking why John calls the Saviour a lamb and not any of these other creatures, and why, when each of the animals that walk is offered of three kinds he used for the sheep-kind the term "lamb".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:5
verses.text: The five animals are as follows: the bullock, the sheep, the goat, the turtle-dove, the pigeon.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:6
verses.text: And of the walking animals these are the three kinds—bullock, ox, calf; ram, sheep, lamb; he-goat, goat, kid.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:7
verses.text: Of the flying animals, of pigeons we only hear of two young ones; of turtle doves only of a pair.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:8
verses.text: He, then, who would accurately understand the spiritual rationale of the sacrifices must enquire of what heavenly things these were the pattern and the shadow, and also for what end the sacrifice of each victim is prescribed, and he must specially collect the points connected with the lamb.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:9
verses.text: Now that the principle of the sacrifice must be apprehended with reference to certain heavenly mysteries, appears from the words of the Apostle, who somewhere says, "Who serve a pattern and shadow of heavenly things," and again, "It was necessary that the patterns of the things in the heavens should be purified with these, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:10
verses.text: Now to find out all the particulars of these and to state in its relation to them that sacrifice of the spiritual law which took place in Jesus Christ (a truth greater than human nature can comprehend)—to do this belongs to no other than the perfect man, who, by reason of use, has his senses exercised to discern good and evil, and who is able to say, from a truth-loving disposition, "We speak wisdom among them that are perfect".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 32:11
verses.text: Of these things truly and things like these, we can say, "Which none of the rulers of this world knew".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:1
verses.text: A Lamb Was Offered at the Morning and Evening Sacrifice.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:2
verses.text: Significance of This.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:3
verses.text: Now we find the lamb offered in the continual (daily) sacrifice.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:4
verses.text: Thus it is written, "This is that which thou shalt offer upon the altar; two lambs of the first year day by day continually, for a continual sacrifice.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:5
verses.text: The one lamb thou shalt offer in the morning, and the other lamb thou shalt offer at even, and a tenth part of fine flour mingled with beaten oil, the fourth part of a hin; and for a drink-offering the fourth part of a bin of wine to the first lamb.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:6
verses.text: And the other lamb thou shalt offer in the evening, according to the first sacrifice and according to its drink-offering.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:7
verses.text: Thou shalt offer a sweet savour, an offering to the Lord, a continual burnt offering throughout your generations at the door of tent of witness before the Lord, where I will make myself known to thee, to speak unto thee.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:8
verses.text: And I will appoint thee for the children of Israel, and I will be sanctified in my glory, and with sanctification I will sanctify the tent of witness".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:9
verses.text: But what other continual sacrifice can there be to the man of reason in the world of mind, but the Word growing to maturity, the Word who is symbolically called a lamb and who is offered as soon as the soul receives illumination.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:10
verses.text: This would be the continual sacrifice of the morning, and it is offered again when the sojourn of the mind with divine things comes to an end.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 33:11
verses.text: For it cannot maintain for ever its intercourse with higher things, seeing that the soul is appointed to be yoked together with the body which is of earth and heavy.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34:1
verses.text: The Morning and Evening Sacrifices of the Saint in His Life of Thought.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34:2
verses.text: But if any one asks what the saint is to do in the time between morning and evening, let him follow what takes place in the cultus and infer from it the principle he asks for.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34:3
verses.text: In that case the priests begin their offerings with the continual sacrifice, and before they come to the continuous one of the evening they offer the other sacrifices which the law prescribes, as, for example, that for transgression, or that for involuntary offences, or that connected with a prayer for salvation, or that of jealousy, or that of the Sabbath, or of the new moon, and so on, which it would take too long to mention.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34:4
verses.text: So we, beginning our oblation with the discourse of that type which is Christ, can go on to discourse about many other most useful things.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 34:5
verses.text: And drawing to a close still in the things of Christ, we come, as it were, to evening and night, when we arrive at the bodily features of His manifestation.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:1
verses.text: Jesus is a Lamb in Respect of His Human Nature.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:2
verses.text: If we enquire further into the significance of Jesus being pointed out by John, when he says, "This is the Lamb of God which taketh away the sin of the world," we may take our stand at the dispensation of the bodily advent of the Son of God in human life, and in that case we shall conceive the lamb to be no other than the man.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:3
verses.text: For the man "was led like a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb, dumb before his shearers," saying, "I was as like a gentle lamb led to the slaughter".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:4
verses.text: Hence, too, in the Apocalypse a lamb is seen, standing as if slain.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:5
verses.text: This slain lamb has been made, according to certain hidden reasons, a purification of the whole world, for which, according to the Father's love to man, He submitted to death, purchasing us back by His own blood from him who had got us into his power, sold under sin.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:6
verses.text: And He who led this lamb to the slaughter was God in man, the great High-Priest, as he shows by the words: "No one taketh My life away from Me, but I lay it down of Myself.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 35:7
verses.text: I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again".

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:1
verses.text: Of the Death of the Martyrs Considered as a Sacrifice, and in What Way It Operates to the Benefit of Others.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:2
verses.text: Akin to this sacrifice are the others of which the sacrifices of the law are symbols, and another kind of sacrifice also appears to me to be of the same nature; namely, the shedding of the blood of the noble martyrs, whom the disciple John saw, for this is not without significance, standing beside the heavenly altar.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:3
verses.text: "Who is wise, and he shall understand these things, prudent, and he shall know them?" It is a matter of higher speculation to consider even slightly the rationale of those sacrifices which cleanse those for whom they are offered.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:4
verses.text: Jephthah's sacrifice of his daughter should receive attention; it was by vowing it that he conquered the children of Ammon, and the victim approved his vow, for when her father said, "I have opened my mouth unto the Lord against thee," she answered, "If thou hast opened thy mouth unto the Lord against me, do that which thou hast vowed".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:5
verses.text: The story suggests that the being must be a very cruel one to whom such sacrifices are offered for the salvation of men; and we require some breadth of mind and some ability to solve the difficulties raised against Providence, to be able to account for such things and to see that they are mysteries and exceed our human nature.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:6
verses.text: Then we shall say, "Great are the judgments of God, and hard to be described; for this cause untutored souls have gone astray".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:7
verses.text: Among the Gentiles, too, it is recorded that many a one, when pestilential disease broke out in his country, offered himself a victim for the public good.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:8
verses.text: That this was the case the faithful Clement assumes, on the faith of the narratives, to whom Paul bears witness when he says, "With Clement also, and the others, my fellow-labourers, whose names are in the book of life".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:9
verses.text: If there is anything in these narratives that appears incongruous to one who is minded to carp at mysteries revealed to few, the same difficulty attaches to the office that was laid on the martyrs, for it was God's will that we should rather endure all the dreadful reproaches connected with confessing Him as God, than escape for a short time from such sufferings (which men count evil) by allowing ourselves by our words to conform to the will of the enemies of the truth.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:10
verses.text: We are, therefore, led to believe that the powers of evil do suffer defeat by the death of the holy martyrs; as if their patience, their confession, even unto death, and their zeal for piety blunted the edge of the onset of evil powers against the sufferer, and their might being thus dulled and exhausted, many others of those whom they had conquered raised their heads and were set free from the weight with which the evil powers formerly oppressed and injured them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:11
verses.text: And even the martyrs themselves are no longer involved in suffering, even though those agents which formerly wrought ill to others are not exhausted; for he who has offered such a sacrifice overcomes the power which opposed him, as I may show by an illustration which is suited to this subject.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:12
verses.text: He who destroys a poisonous animal, or lulls it to sleep with charms, or by any means deprives it of its venom, he does good to many who would otherwise have suffered from that animal had it not been destroyed, or charmed, or emptied of its venom.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:13
verses.text: Moreover, if one of those who were formerly bitten should come to know of this, and should be cured of his malady and look upon the death of that which injured him, or tread on it, or touch it when dead, or taste a part of it, then he, who was formerly a sufferer, would owe cure and benefit to the destroyer of the poisonous animal.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 36:14
verses.text: In some such way must we suppose the death of the most holy martyrs to operate, many receiving benefit from it by an influence we cannot describe.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:1
verses.text: Of the Effects of the Death of Christ, of His Triumph After It, and of the Removal by His Death of the Sins of Men.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:2
verses.text: We have lingered over this subject of the martyrs and over the record of those who died on account of pestilence, because this lets us see the excellence of Him who was led as a sheep to the slaughter and was dumb as a lamb before the shearer.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:3
verses.text: For if there is any point in these stories of the Greeks, and if what we have said of the martyrs is well founded,—the Apostles, too, were for the same reason the filth of the world and the offscouring of all things,—what and how great things must be said of the Lamb of God, who was sacrificed for this very reason, that He might take away the sin not of a few but of the whole world, for the sake of which also He suffered? If any one sin, we read, "We have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous; and He is the propitiation for our sins, and not for ours only, but for those of the whole world," since He is the Saviour of all men, especially of them that believe, who blotted out the written bond that was against us by His own blood, and took it out of the way, so that not even a trace, not even of our blotted-out sins, might still be found, and nailed it to His cross; who having put off from Himself the principalities and powers, made a show of them openly, triumphing over them by His cross.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:4
verses.text: And we are taught to rejoice when we suffer afflictions in the world, knowing the ground of our rejoicing to be this, that the world has been conquered and has manifestly been subjected to its conqueror.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:5
verses.text: Hence all the nations, released from their former rulers, serve Him, because He saved the poor from his tyrant by His own passion, and the needy who had no helper.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:6
verses.text: This Saviour, then, having humbled the calumniator by humbling Himself, abides with the visible sun before His illustrious church, tropically called the moon, from generation to generation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:7
verses.text: And having by His passion destroyed His enemies, He who is strong in battle and a mighty Lord required after His mighty deeds a purification which could only be given Him by His Father alone; and this is why He forbids Mary to touch Him, saying, "Touch Me not, for I am not yet ascended to My Father; but go and tell My disciples, I go to My Father and your Father, to My God and your God".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:8
verses.text: And when He comes, loaded with victory and with trophies, with His body which has risen from the dead,—for what other meaning can we see in the words, "I am not yet ascended to My Father," and "I go unto My Father,"—then there are certain powers which say, Who is this that cometh from Edom, red garments from Bosor; this that is beautiful? Then those who escort Him say to those that are upon the heavenly gates, "Lift up your gates, ye rulers, and be ye lifted up, ye everlasting doors, and the king of glory shall come in".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:9
verses.text: But they ask again, seeing as it were His right hand red with blood and His whole person covered with the marks of His valour, "Why are Thy garments red, and Thy clothes like the treading of the full winefat when it is trodden?" And to this He answers, "I have crushed them".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:10
verses.text: For this cause He had need to wash "His robe in wine, and His garment in the blood of the grape".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:11
verses.text: For when He had taken up our infirmities and carried our diseases, and had borne the sin of the whole world, and had conferred blessings on so many, then, perhaps, He received that baptism which is greater than any that could ever be conceived among men, and of which I think He speaks when He says, "I have a baptism to be baptized with, and how am I straitened till it be accomplished?" I enquire here with boldness and I challenge the ideas put forward by most writers.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:12
verses.text: They say that the greatest baptism, beyond which no greater can be conceived, is His passion.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:13
verses.text: But if this be so, why should He say to Mary after it, "Touch Me not"? He should rather have offered Himself to her touch, when by His passion He had received His perfect baptism.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:14
verses.text: But if it was the case, as we said before, that after all His deeds of valour done against His enemies, He had need to wash "His robe in wine, His garment in the blood of the grape," then He was on His way up to the husbandman of the true vine, the Father, so that having washed there and after having gone up on high, He might lead captivity captive and come down bearing manifold gifts—the tongues, as of fire, which were divided to the Apostles, and the holy angels which are to be present with them in each action and to deliver them.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:15
verses.text: For before these economies they were not yet cleansed and angels could not dwell with them, for they too perhaps do not desire to be with those who have not prepared themselves nor been cleansed by Jesus.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:16
verses.text: For it was of Jesus' benignity alone that He ate and drank with publicans and sinners, and suffered the penitent woman who was a sinner to wash His feet with her tears, and went down even to death for the ungodly, counting it not robbery to be equal with God, and emptied Himself, assuming the form of a servant.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:17
verses.text: And in accomplishing all this He fulfils rather the will of the Father who gave Him up for sinners than His own.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:18
verses.text: For the Father is good, but the Saviour is the image of His goodness; and doing good to the world in all things, since God was in Christ reconciling the world to Himself, which formerly for its wickedness was all enemy to Him, He accomplishes His good deeds in order and succession, and does not all at once take all His enemies for His footstool.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:19
verses.text: For the Father says to Him, to the Lord of us all, "Sit Thou on My right hand, until I make Thy enemies the footstool of Thy feet".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:20
verses.text: And this goes on till the last enemy, Death, is overcome by Him.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:21
verses.text: And if we consider what is meant by this subjection to Christ and find an explanation of this mainly from the saying, "When all things shall have been put under Him, then shall the Son Himself be subjected to Him who put all things under Him," then we shall see how the conception agrees with the goodness of the God of all, since it is that of the Lamb of God, taking away the sin of the world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:22
verses.text: Not all men's sin, however, is taken away by the Lamb of God, not the sin of those who do not grieve and suffer affliction till it be taken away.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:23
verses.text: For thorns are not only fixed but deeply rooted in the hand of every one who is intoxicated by wickedness and has parted with sobriety, as it is said in the Proverbs, "Thorns grow in the hand of the drunkard," and what pain they must cause him who has admitted such growth in the substance of his soul, it is hard even to tell.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:24
verses.text: Who has allowed wickedness to establish itself so deeply in his soul as to be a ground full of thorns, he must be cut down by the quick and powerful word of God, which is sharper than a two-edged sword, and which is more caustic than any fire.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:25
verses.text: To such a soul that fire must be sent which finds out thorns, and by its divine virtue stands where they are and does not also burn up the threshing-floors or standing corn.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:26
verses.text: But of the Lamb which takes away the sin of the world and begins to do so by His own death there are several ways, some of which are capable of being clearly understood by most, but others are concealed from most, and are known to those only who are worthy of divine wisdom.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:27
verses.text: Why should we count up all the ways by which we come to believe among men? That is a thing which every one living in the body is able to see for himself.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:28
verses.text: And in the ways in which we believe in these also, sin is taken away; by afflictions and evil spirits and dangerous diseases and grievous sicknesses.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:29
verses.text: And who knows what follows after this? So much as we have said was not unnecessary—we could not neglect the thought which is so clearly connected with that of the words, "Behold the Lamb of God that taketh away the sin of the world," and had therefore to attend somewhat closely to this part of our subject.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 37:30
verses.text: This has brought us to see that God convicts some by His wrath and chastens them by His anger, since His love to men is so great that He will not leave any without conviction and chastening; so that we should do what in us lies to be spared such conviction and such chastening by the sorest trials.

chapters.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:1
verses.text: The World, of Which the Sin is Taken Away, is Said to Be the Church.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:2
verses.text: Reasons for Not Agreeing with This Opinion.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:3
verses.text: The reader will do well to consider what was said above and illustrated from various quarters on the question what is meant in Scripture by the word "world"; and I think it proper to repeat this.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:4
verses.text: I am aware that a certain scholar understands by the world the Church alone, since the Church is the adornment of the world, and is said to be the light of the world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:5
verses.text: "You," he says, "are the light of the world".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:6
verses.text: Now, the adornment of the world is the Church, Christ being her adornment, who is the first light of the world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:7
verses.text: We must consider if Christ is said to be the light of the same world as His disciples.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:8
verses.text: When Christ is the light of the world, perhaps it is meant that He is the light of the Church, but when His disciples are the light of the world, perhaps they are the light of others who call on the Lord, others in addition to the Church, as Paul says on this point in the beginning of his first Epistle to the Corinthians, where he writes, "To the Church of God, with all who call on the name of the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:9
verses.text: Should any one consider that the Church is called the light of the world, meaning thereby of the rest of the race of men, including unbelievers, this may be true if the assertion is taken prophetically and theologically; but if it is to be taken of the present, we remind him that the light of a thing illuminates that thing, and would ask him to show how the remainder of the race is illuminated by the Church's presence in the world.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:10
verses.text: If those who hold the view in question cannot show this, then let them consider if our interpretation is not a sound one, that the light is the Church, and the world those others who call on the Name.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:11
verses.text: The words which follow the above in Matthew will point out to the careful enquirer the proper interpretation.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:12
verses.text: "You," it is said, "are the salt of the earth," the rest of mankind being conceived as the earth, and believers are their salt; it is because they believe that the earth is preserved.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:13
verses.text: For the end will come if the salt loses its savour, and ceases to salt and preserve the earth, since it is clear that if iniquity is multiplied and love waxes cold upon the earth, as the Saviour Himself uttered an expression of doubt as to those who would witness His coming, saying, "When the Son of man cometh, shall He find faith upon the earth?" then the end of the age will come.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:14
verses.text: Supposing, then, the Church to be called the world, since the Saviour's light shines on it—we have to ask in connection with the text, "Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world," whether the world here is to be taken intellectually of the Church, and the taking away of sin is limited to the Church.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:15
verses.text: In that case what are we to make of the saying of the same disciple with regard to the Saviour, as the propitiation for sin? "If any man sin," we read, "we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous; and He is the propitiation for our sins, and not for our sins only, but for the sins of the whole world?" Paul's dictum appears to me to be to the same effect, when he says, "Who is the Saviour of all men, especially of the faithful".

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:16
verses.text: Again, Heracleon, dealing with our passage, declares, without any proof or any citation of witnesses to that effect, that the words, "Lamb of God," are spoken by John as a prophet, but the words, "who taketh away the sin of the world," by John as more than a prophet.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:17
verses.text: The former expression he considers to be used of His body, but the latter of Him who was in that body, because the lamb is an imperfect member of the genus sheep; the same being true of the body as compared with the dweller in it.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:18
verses.text: Had he meant to attribute perfection to the body he would have spoken of a ram as about to be sacrificed.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:19
verses.text: After the careful discussions given above, I do not think it necessary to enter into repetitions on this passage, or to controvert Heracleon's careless utterances.

verses.name: Origen's Commentary on the Gospel of John Book VI 38:20
verses.text: One point only may be noted, that as the world was scarcely able to contain Him who had emptied Himself, it required a lamb and not a ram, that its sin might be taken away.
